awd_titl_txt: Hierarchical Assembly of Liposomes with Shape-Controlled Metal Nanoparticles for Multifunctional Theranostics
awd_abstract_narration:
Multifunctional nanoparticles that simultaneously enable targeted diagnosis of a disease and delivery of a therapeutic drug are of significant interest to achieving highly specific disease detection and treatment in a single procedure.  In this work a single multifunctional nanoparticle, Lipo-Nanoantennas, will be nanomanufactured for combined therapeutics and diagnostics (theranostics) in cancer cells. Lipo-Nanoantennas will ultimately facilitate a clinically applicable technology which can be translated from "bench to bedside" allowing minimally invasive imaging of cancer biomarkers with high precision. Lipo-Nanoantennas will also simultaneously deliver dose-controlled treatment minimizing off-target toxicities associated with chemotherapy.  Further, Lipo-Nanoantennas may allow early detection and targeted treatment of multiple diseases including cardiovascular and infectious diseases.  Successful implementation of the project goals will ultimately enable us to generate a library of functional nanomaterial assemblies that will impact multiple technologies including sensing, catalysis, and self-healing coatings. Notably, this project also builds an interface between the PI's research and core undergraduate chemical engineering curriculum where the PI teaches a drug delivery laboratory. Further, this work will increase participation of underrepresented minorities at the graduate and undergraduate level in the PI's lab, and propel research-based outreach activities among K-12 students.

The objective of this award is to study the hierarchical assembly of thermosensitive liposomes with gold nanoantennas (Lipo-Nanoantennas) to enable multifunctional theranostics.  This will leverage directed self-assembly, a bottom-up nanomanufacturing approach, that offers nanoscale control of material properties critical to enabling enhanced theranostics. Liposomes are clinically-approved drug carriers and nanoantennas are ideally suited for both imaging and converting near-infrared light to heat. Heat generated by the nanoantennas is absorbed by the liposomes disrupting the lipid bilayer and triggering drug release. Directed assembly of Lipo-Nanoantennas provides a mechanistic design of a nanomanufactured construct that can leverage intense photothermal response directly at the point of drug release.  This gives rise to highly efficient photothermal drug delivery with minimal off-target toxicity and precise cellular imaging all with a single nanoscale entity. By controlling the loading density and shape of gold nanostructures within the liposomes, and their overall size and material properties, the photothermal response of Lipo-Nanoantennas will be manipulated to promote enhanced uptake, imaging, and drug release in cells. The Lipo-Nanoantennas will then be utilized for surface-enhanced Raman imaging and delivery of chemotherapeutic drugs in cancer cells. Our central hypothesis is that understanding directed-assembly of Lipo-Nanoantennas will offer a transformative approach relative to other methods that will simultaneously enable superior biophysical properties, and theranostics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Theranostic nanoparticles are multifunctional agents that simultaneously enable targeted diagnosis of the disease and deliver a therapeutic function enabling highly specific disease detection and treatment in a single procedure. In this work, we designed hybrid liposomal architectures where we hierarchically assembled liposomes with gold nanoparticles that enabled therapeutic delivery of drugs in cancer cells. We also designed liposomes loaded with two different molecules – one with therapeutic capability to reduce hypoxia in tumor microenvironment, and a near infrared fluorescent dye that can be used both to image the cancer cells as well as when excited with light, converts light to heat and induce photothermal therapy to ablate the cancer cells. The utility of gold nanoparticles or molecular dye enables spatiotemporal control of therapeutic delivery of drugs where the laser power and duration can be modulated to facilitate mild hyperthermia of <45 C. At this temperature cells undergo apoptotic cell death instead of necrotic ablation that can induce further immune response in mouse models.  Therefore, our directed assembly approach provides a mechanistic design of a nanomanufactured construct that can leverage highly efficient drug delivery with minimal off-target toxicity and precise cellular imaging all with a single nanoscale entity. Through our systematic work we have shown that directed-assembly of liposomal constructs offer a transformative approach relative to other methods that simultaneously allow superior light to heat conversion, enhanced cellular uptake and biocompatibility, and multifunctional theranostics.

Broader Impacts:

The outcome of this work has broadly impacted a range of hybrid liposomal constructs where both gold nanoparticles and therapeutic molecules have been assembled with liposomes enabling a generalized approach to designing a library of multifunctional assemblies with unique properties that will ultimately impact multiple technologies including sensing, biomedical imaging, and therapy. Further, we have also used these liposomal constructs in new treatment strategies such as cancer immunotherapies. This implies that liposomal constructs could ultimately facilitate clinically applicable technologies which can be translated from bench to bedside enabling noninvasive longitudinal tracking of cancer biomarkers and eliminating the need for invasive biopsies. Our universal approach will also enable highly controlled early detection and targeted treatment of multiple diseases beyond cancer including multiple sclerosis, cardiovascular and inflammatory diseases.  This project has also build an interface between the PI’s research and the undergraduate science and engineering curriculum at Vanderbilt University where the PI taught a laboratory module on metal nanoparticle synthesis and therapeutics.  The funding from this work enabled the PI to directly engage undergraduate and K-12 students in the classroom and research lab educating them on concepts from this work. Further, the PI and the funded graduate students actively participated in outreach activities aimed to promote hands-on learning in nanoscience among K-12 students, and provide excitement to pursue careers in STEM.

Summary Statement: In summary we designed two different directed assemblies with liposomes with gold nanoparticles and with therapuetic molecules to ultimately achieve cellular uptake and targeted image-guided therapuetics. These work are still ongoing and will culminate at the end of this year. Graduate students funded on this grant published several papers and we also actively participated in outreach activities to educate K-12 stduents.

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2022
Modified by: Rizia Bardhan
